article.description: The Chicago Bulls brushed aside their turmoil Tuesday night and produced the most lopsided victory in coach Tim Floyd's four seasons.

related.description: One day after reportedly telling his players during a team meeting that he was going to ask team management to relieve him of his duties, Tim Floyd told the Chicago Bulls on Tuesday he would not step down as coach.
related.linkText: Frustrated Floyd tells Bulls he's not stepping down
related.title: Floyd says he won't quit on Bulls
related.headline: Floyd says he won't quit on Bulls

article.headline: Bulls get Floyd largest victory margin

images.name: Floyd_Tim 120401 inline
images.caption: Tim Floyd was in a joking mood after enjoying his biggest win as a pro coach.

article.linkText: Rally 'round the Floyd: Bulls rout Rockets
article.story:
CHICAGO (AP) -- For one night at least, the Chicago Bulls soothed the frustrations of coach Tim Floyd, giving him his most lopsided win since taking the job four seasons ago. "Winning is the cure all," guard Greg Anthony said after the Bulls routed Houston 103-75 Tuesday night, sending the tired and depleted Rockets to their seventh straight loss. "It makes a team closer. You are always going to have adversity in this business and you have to separate that once you take the basketball court," Anthony added. "It is a little more difficult because of the frustrations and the turmoil this team has gone through the past four years." Floyd wouldn't comment before Tuesday's game on reports that he told his players at a Monday meeting that he was going to ask general manager Jerry Krause to relieve him of his duties. At the team's morning shootaround, he said he had no intention of quitting although he did not deny the reports in two Chicago papers. After the game when asked if the circumstances of the previous two days sparked his team to victory, Floyd replied sarcastically: "It was a big trick." Ron Mercer led the Bulls (3-13) with 22 points, Marcus Fizer added 17 points and rookie Trenton Hassell had 15 as Chicago shot 54 percent. The Bulls' previous biggest win under Floyd was by 18 points. Houston, playing its fourth game in five nights without injured star and leading scorer Steve Francis, was led by 12 points from Moochie Norris. "We should be embarrassed," Houston's Glen Rice said. "We are a better team than we showed. We never should have looked at Chicago and seen them as an easy win." The Bulls hit 13 of their 21 first-quarter shots and Hassell finished the first half by going 5-for-5. When Hassell banked in a 3-pointer to cap a 17-5 second-quarter run, the Bulls had a 21-point lead, 55-34, and were shooting 56 percent. The lead grew to 72-44 in the third quarter before a 17-2 Houston rally got the Rockets within 13 early in the final quarter, but the Bulls pulled away again behind their reserves. "We've been struggling, but we're not giving up and coach Floyd is not giving up," Fizer said. Floyd's career NBA coaching record is now 48-182. "There are not a lot of coaches who could do a great job having gone through and endured the type of losing he has the past three or four years," Anthony said. "It's a tough job and I told him that to his face. He's got a difficult job."

Game notes
Francis, with ruptured tissue in the arch of his left foot, missed the 13th game of his NBA career. The Rockets are 3-10 in those games. ... Bulls F Eddie Robinson, who has played only three games all season because of an injury to his left toe, said he will get an injection in the toe as a last option before surgery that could knock him out for the rest of the season. ... The blowout win allowed the Bulls the rare luxury of playing prep-to-pro rookies Eddy Curry and Tyson Chandler together for the final six minutes.

statistics.name: points
statistics.description: The number of points scored.

statistics.name: fieldGoals
statistics.description: Field Goal makes and attempts.

statistics.name: freeThrows
statistics.description: Free Throw makes and attempts.

statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.name: rebounds
statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.name: defensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.

statistics.description: The number of times when the offense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot.
